awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dielectric Screening in Structured Polymer Electrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports theoretical and computational research, software development, and education efforts on ion-containing polymeric materials. This family of materials has demonstrated great promise for use as a separation component in batteries that power light-weight electronic devices such as cell phones. Energy storage and release in batteries relies on the directed shuttling of positively charged chemical species inside a separation medium or electrolyte. The conventional electrolyte is normally a liquid which conducts ions efficiently.  Often the liquid can be too chemically reactive, leading to safety concerns. Polymers are promising replacements. Polymers are large, chain-like molecules from which, for example, plastic bags, fibers, and tires are made. They can be engineered to behave as solids at room temperature and show modest chemical reactivity. In this project, the PI aims to develop theoretical and computational tools to understand the physical and chemical properties of these kind of materials.
The PI plans to develop theoretical concepts and computer simulation algorithms to address the critical material science problems underlying the design of polymer electrolytes. At the heart of this problem is an intimate connection among the structure or the architecture of the material at the atomic scale, the morphology or the form of the material, and functionality or how the components interact with each other. To understand the multitude of possible properties, theoretical approaches and computational algorithms will be developed to enable simulation of candidate polymer electrolyte materials across length scales. These efforts will be backed by extensive experimental collaborations, which will provide the fundamental understanding necessary to advance the rational design of these polymeric materials.
The broader impacts of the research include training high school students through the Raising Interest in Science and Engineering program of Stanford University. The students will participate in the design of novel simulation algorithms and in the creation of a database of materials properties that will be accessible to the broader scientific community to aid in the design of materials. The PI will work to broaden the diversity of the scientific community by educating leading theoretical researchers to solve tackle challenging questions crucial to quantitative material design. These efforts will be integrated through interaction with a local community college. The developed software package facilitating the experimental screening will be shared with the public.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports a theoretical and computational study and education focused on dielectric properties of ion-containing block copolymers, a particularly promising candidate for use in electrolyte membranes in lithium-ion batteries. The ability of block copolymers to self-assemble into spatially heterogeneous morphologies provides a unique opportunity for engineering the mechanical properties and ion-conductivity simultaneously inside the same material. At the same time, it poses fundamental challenges on studying the electrostatic interaction in structured electrolytes with a low average dielectric permittivity. Low permittivity implies strong correlation inside the materials, and structured electrolytes demand expensive calculations to resolve the electrostatic potential from Poisson's equation. 

Four interrelated research objectives are identified that address different aspects of dielectric screening in structured block copolymers with comparatively low permittivity. The first objective develops field theory for heterogeneous polymer electrolytes and a symmetry-adapted software package, based on ionic polymer self-consistent field theory. The second objective identifies the distinct phase behaviors governed by the competing effects of entropy and electrostatic interaction and enables the development of analytical theory near critical points. The third objective examines how strong ionic correlation impacts the miscibility of polymer blends by combining experiments with modeling to generalize the Debye-Huckel theory. The fourth objective aims to extract mesoscale solvation and screening parameters from atomistic simulations, which will reveal the microscopic dielectric screening mechanism in these materials and provide the foundation for continuum field theory. These four objectives, which span theory, simulation, and experiments, are expected to provide a coherent picture of ionic interactions in structured polymer electrolytes.
This research represents a fundamental multi-scale study of the electrostatic interactions between ionic species in structured polymer electrolytes. Developing field theories enables efficient screening of the parameter space. Performing atomistic simulations enables the estimation of phenomenological parameters used in field theory, and thus allows assumptions to be tested. Combining these two approaches presents an opportunity to elucidate the fundamental physics which dictate non-local and nonlinear electrostatic interactions in dielectrically heterogeneous media. This serves as a stepping stone for designing coarse-grained simulations to investigate the dynamics and effects of composition fluctuations. The developed methodology will prove useful for the study of other electrostatics-driven self-assembly phenomena at the molecular level.

The broader impacts of the research include training high school students through the Raising Interest in Science and Engineering program of Stanford University. The students will participate in the design of novel simulation algorithms and in the creation of a database of materials properties that will be accessible to the broader scientific community to aid in the design of materials. The PI will work to broaden the diversity of the scientific community by educating leading theoretical researchers to tackle and solve challenging questions crucial to quantitative material design. These efforts will be integrated through interaction with a local community college. The developed software package facilitating the experimental screening will be shared with the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Much of the energy storage, conversion, and biological applications are based on the molecular scale understanding of electrostatic interactions. Being able to tune, control, and model the ionic and electronic solvation and transports at will is fundamental to the success of engineering approaches. This poses an important challenge in that the electrostatic interactions are long-ranged, and many applications involves the dielectrically heterogeneous medium. The basic physics that have to be treated reliably and efficiently includes the degree of ion solvation, the mutual ionic interaction, as well as ionic screening. In polymeric or organic electrolytes, such tasks are particularly difficulty to resolves because the average dielectric permittivity is low, which makes the electrostatic interactions all the more stronger. Moreover, working with heterogeneous dielectric medium implies that the screening effects in the medium is spatially varying, which requires the further treatments of polarization. This project develops minimum theoretical modeling for electrostatic screening effects in such low-permittivity medium, and focuses on the study of ionic polymers because of their potential as solid state electrolytes.

Our primary outcome is the development of a theoretical modeling package that solves the electrostatic interaction in such medium, allowing us to systematically investigate the interplay of multiple competing physical effects. The first effect is ion solvation, which measures the work that has to be done in order to dissolve ions in an dielectric medium and which favors the preferential ion solvation in domains with higher permittivity. The second effect is the translational entropy of ions and any other mixed chemicals, which measures the propensity of ions to become delocalized spatially in order to maximize the entropy. The third effect is the inter-ionic interactions, which is intrinsically a many-body effects and which is treated in our work at both mean-field level and at the level of Debye-Hueckel screening. The fourth effect is the polymerical aspects of the dielectric medium, which explicitly considered the conformational degree of freedom of polymers and which is integrated with the treatment of solvation and electrostatics. Taken together, the model we developed allows us to make predictions on the spatial distribution of ionic species, on the morphology of the self-assembled structures in salt-doped homopolymers and block copolymers, and on the length scale that emerges as a result of these competing factors.

Using the tools developed, several interesting and unique physics have been revealed. We showed that indeed selective ion solvation competes with the translational entropy of ions, leading to presence of two distinct thermodynamic regimes, one dominated by solvation and another by entropy. The solvation-dominated regime favors the ion-induced ordering, whereas the entropy-dominated regimes favors spatially homogeneous structures. Such pictures have been found to compare favorably with the independently conducted experiments.

In order to understand the nature of such competition more deeply, we developed purely analytical theory to study how different types of physics compete with each other. The idea is to expand the free energy of the system in terms of possible density modulations, the latter needed to capture or define the self-assembled structure. The stability of the given density modulation is determined by the value of free energy. By studying such stability in different types of spatially modulated structures, we were able to definitively verify the opposite role played by entropy and solvation. Moreover, this new theoretical tools allows us to consider the effects of composition on spatial ordering. The compositional fluctuation generally weakens the degrees of ordering. We showed, by applying our analytical theory, that such fluctuation effects do effectively weaken the stability of ordered morphologies induced by dissolving ions in block polymers. The theoretical analyses suggests furthermore that all the competitive factors may be present in homopolymer blends as well. We therefore showed, additionally, that the competition between selective ion solvation, ionic mixing entropy, and the requirement of charge neutrality may leads to emergence of mesophases in salt-doped homopolymer blends, which has not been noted in the previous studies.

Our researches rely essentially on molecular thermodynamics. While work on our project, we developed the T-Farm database (thermodynamic database on the farm), which is publicly accessible, is meant to facilitate the teaching of thermodynamics in chemical science, and contains three moduli. The first modulus is a searchable and interpolated table for the equation of states of nonideal fluid. The second modulus is the algebraic helper that allows students to reduce all standard partial derivatives of the one-component fluids into 3 experimental measurable quantities. The third modulus contains the lecture note and discussion points on the subtle concepts that cannot be adequately covered in the standard teaching setting, so serves as extended learning resources.
